intro: Welcome to our heat exploration! Observe how heat moves between the two objects. Try adjusting the temperatures to see what happens.

questions.question: When Object A is hot (red) and Object B is cold (blue), what do you observe about the movement of heat particles?
options: A) Heat particles move from Object B to Object A.
B) Heat particles move from Object A to Object B.
D) Heat particles move equally in both directions.
questions.hint: Pay close attention to the color of the objects and the direction the orange particles are flowing.
questions.explanation: Heat always flows from a hotter object to a colder object. In the simulation, the hotter object (Object A, red) transfers heat energy to the colder object (Object B, blue).

questions.question: What happens to the rate of heat flow if you make Object A much hotter and Object B much colder?
options: A) The heat flow slows down.
B) The heat flow stops completely.
C) The heat flow speeds up significantly.
D) The direction of heat flow reverses.
questions.hint: Try setting the temperature sliders to their extreme values and observe the animation.
questions.explanation: The greater the difference in temperature between two objects, the faster heat will flow between them. Making one object very hot and the other very cold creates a larger temperature difference, leading to a faster heat transfer.

questions.question: Which real-life situation best demonstrates the flow of heat from a hotter object to a colder object?
options: A) An ice pack cooling your forehead.
C) A hot air balloon rising.
D) A refrigerator keeping food cold.
questions.hint: Think about which object is hotter and which is colder in each scenario.
questions.explanation: When you put an ice pack on your forehead, the hotter object (your forehead) transfers heat energy to the colder object (the ice pack). Options B and C involve radiation and convection respectively, and while they involve heat transfer, option A is the most direct example of heat flowing from a warmer to a cooler object in the context of the simulation's primary principle.

followups: Try setting both objects to the same temperature. What do you notice now?
Can you make the heat flow stop completely by adjusting the temperatures?
Challenge: Can you make the heat flow in the opposite direction of what you saw in the first question?
summary: We learned that heat always moves from hotter to colder objects. The bigger the temperature difference, the faster the heat flows. This fundamental principle helps us understand many everyday phenomena!
